What I'm going to do now is just develop the narrative that we started to talk about 6 months ago, which I know you all found absolutely riveting, and you're going to be delighted to come back to it.

At the moment, the central overheads of the business are around GBP 230 million.
This is -- these are cash costs.
So they -- doesn't include depreciation, does include an allowance, GBP 16 million allowance for maintenance.
And if we break that down into the constituent parts.

Within each one of those areas, there is actually quite a lot of variable costs.
If we pick less in our warehouses, we'll spend less money on pickers.
If we have fewer stores, then marketing costs will come down because a lot of that cost are window dressers.
Fewer stores, fewer windows, fewer window dressers.
If we say the minus 6% scenario would give us a drop in sales of 57%, the reason that that's more, I can see instantly you've all added it up, 6% compound, couldn't possibly come to minus 57%.
The reason that it comes to more than that is because of the store closures.
But if we model that drop in sales and say, well, what variable costs would automatically drop out of the business, it will be around 20% drop in those central overheads.

If we assume, as it has done this year, that Directory grows as much as retail declines, then the cost that retail pays for the central overheads will decline, but that will be paid for by the growth in the Directory business.
And put it another way, you would still need those central costs to run the Directory business whether or not you had a retail business.
It's just, in a way, the subsidy that retail will pay will come down.
If you take out those shared costs, all the costs will be reallocated toward Directory, they drop to about 22%.
Further cost savings, we think, can get at around 6%.
These are sort of semi-variable costs.
Things like our retail hubs.
Some of the leases will expire over the next 10 years.
We won't just renew them in the same shape and size, and in fact, we're already looking at plans to consolidate 2 hubs into one which will save us significant amount of money.
So overall, we get to around 52% of the central overheads.
That's around GBP 120 million of cost.
Model that across the entire portfolio, and this is -- these are making allowances for 2 things.

First of all, continued spend of capital on cosmetics, still spending GBP 16 million a year all the way through on cosmetics, and also assuming that wages continue to grow faster than inflation by around 1%.
Put those together, you end up with cash flow of around GBP 1 billion.
So when we're thinking about sort of asset or liability, we think actually, even in this worst case scenario, asset of GBP 1 billion.
If you look at the minus 2%, that GBP 1 billion would come to around GBP 2 billion.
So we think the retail portfolio, as an asset to the businesses, were in terms of future cash flow somewhere between GBP 1 billion and GBP 2 billion.
And you can all go through and discount that at the rates you like and come to sort of nitty gritty valuation, which I'm sure we'll enjoy.
However, it's not quite the whole story because some of the assumptions we've made are definitely not right.
First of all, we will open new stores; and secondly, we will -- are more than likely, in an environment of minus 6% like-for-like sales, to experience some rent reductions.
Taking each one of those in turn.
And I feel I have re-explain this many, many times because it is so counterintuitive.
People say, "Why on earth are you opening stores in an environment of declining like-for-like sales?"
And it's a very good question.
And the reason we're opening stores is because the stores we're opening have a quick payback and high profit.
And if we take a store, and this is what we do now, it's a discipline when we open new stores, and say, let's model the minus 6% on the new store that we opened.
So let's take a store, and for ease, say, we invest GBP 1 million in the capital expenditure on that store.
With a 24-month payback, and I should say our 24-month payback assumes 0 like-for-likes, so actually flat, [FX] going down, it would be slightly more than 24 months.
But that means in year 1, you would expect to get cash out of that store of GBP 0.5 million.

Model the cash forward, and you'd expect -- and this is on the basis of a minus 6% like-for-like scenario in that chart, you would expect to get 2.5% -- sorry, GBP 2.5 million back for your GBP 1 million investment.
So as counterintuitive though it is to invest in a store with a declining profit, in cash terms, it's actually a good investment.
And if I put it in another way, if I said, "I've got a bond, and the bond will pay you 50% interest in year 1, but in year 10 will only pay you 4%," you would all buy instantly.
So -- and that is the way that we look at these stores.
We're taking very, very few stores in more than 10-year leases.
Incidentally, the internal rate of return on the money invested in that, if you take the model, run an IRR on it, it comes to around 34%.
So really healthy use of the businesses' capital.
And obviously, the more of these stores were opening, the more of that central overhead we are also recovering.
The second thing is rent reductions.
We have come to the end of 8 stores.
Remember that we closed 10 stores at the end of their lease; another 8, we renewed.
If we look at the rent on those 8 stores, the rent before was GBP 2.9 million; after, GBP 2.2 million.
I should say that GBP 2.2 million accounts for any capital contribution amortizing over the life of the lease.
So that takes the rent to sales in those stores from 9.5% to 7%.
In addition, with open concessions in those stores of around -- which will generate rental income of around GBP 175,000, that's mainly cafs.
That takes the rent-to-sales ratio to 6.5%.
The capital required to maintain a lease -- we normally do go back and spend some capital to maintain a shop, but the average lease length of these renewals is around 7 years.
And the profitability of the stores that we'd renewed on once we've renewed -- reviewed the rent is 23%.

So again, the assumption in our model that we won't get rent reductions certainly in an environment of minus 6% like-for-like, all our experience suggests that, that isn't right and that we would see rent reductions.

They generate quite a lot of rent, around GBP 4.5 million, GBP 5 million of rent for the group.

In Arndale, we're introducing a whole range of different concessions to see what effect they have and whether they're successful or not.

site but not overseas.

site because it takes the majority of our business.
